questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE about Go's if statement?

options.text: Parentheses are required around the condition
Braces {} are optional for single-line bodies
Parentheses are not required around the condition
The condition must be an integer

questions.explanation: Go does not require parentheses around the condition in an if statement, but braces {} are always required.

questions.question: What is the scope of a variable declared in an 'if' initialization statement like 'if y := 20; y > 15'?

options.text: The entire function where the if statement is defined
Only the if block and its corresponding else/else if blocks
Only the if block, but not the else block
The entire package

questions.explanation: Variables declared in the if initialization statement are scoped to the if statement and any associated else if or else blocks.

questions.question: How does Go's switch statement handle case fall-through?

options.text: Cases fall through by default, similar to C or JavaScript
You must use the 'break' keyword to prevent fall-through
Cases do not fall through by default; each case ends automatically
Fall-through is not supported in Go

questions.explanation: In Go, switch cases do not fall through by default. You don't need 'break' statements. If you explicitly want fall-through, you must use the 'fallthrough' keyword.

questions.question: Which keyword is used to explicitly fall through to the next case in a switch statement?

options.text: continue
next
fallthrough
goto

questions.explanation: The 'fallthrough' keyword is used to unconditionally transfer control to the first statement of the next case clause.

questions.question: Does Go have a ternary conditional operator (condition ? val1 : val2)?

options.text: Yes, it works exactly like in C/Java
No, Go requires using an if-else statement instead
Yes, but it uses a different syntax
Only for constant expressions

questions.explanation: Go does not have a ternary operator. The designers of Go chose to omit it to favor the more explicit and readable if-else construct.
